Luiz Siqueira Neto wrote:

> No one of then; my focus is the "state machine"; The "state machine"
> needs entities to play. Let me clarify with a example: Suppose I want
> make a GUI in HTML; well, in my paradigm, everything begins from a
> entity. I need a entity to have a GUI. Than I make a "state machine"
> that receive as "primal material" the entity and as result I have a
> GUI. In this point I know what to wait from the "state machine", than
> I begins to produce the "state machine", testing your result visually
> until I get what I want.
> I create a simple class for have a acceptance test visually; This
> visually test is the most simple solution for know if a GUI looks like
> I want right now.
> Take a look in the "acceptance test"
> [ http://br.geocities.com/cybersamurai_br/ScreenShotFujiyama.JPG 
> <http://br.geocities.com/cybersamurai_br/ScreenShotFujiyama.JPG> ].

All right. I think I understand. We can write the first test for your 
State Machine object. Select a method on it, then choose inputs and the 
output you expect, then write the test. I might try this:

TransitionTable transitionTable =
     TransitionTable.withStartState("a")
                    .withTransition("a", 1, "b")
                    .withEndState("b");

StateMachine stateMachine = new StateMachine(transitionTable);
assertEquals("b", stateMachine.transition("a", 1));
assertTrue(statemAchine.isInEndState());

This is a simple test for a simple state machine. Do your tests need to 
be so different?

> If you have some doubt please tell me. (sorry again about my pour
> English.)
